channel.title: Cache Extractor (C#)
channel.description:
This is something I made today in another attempt to succeed in extracting stuff from the 317 cache. It hit me to look in the startup method where it actually unpacks everything. It was all cake from there.
It's in C#, meaning some things are different. For example, I had to do several changes to get the array belonging to x's index in a 2D array ([s]You can't just do array[index] like in Java[/s] The way I created the 2D arrays was one of the two ways, which was the different-than-Java one). Other than that, the only thing that changed was the sprite extracting method, some syntax stuff, and IO classes.
I'm supplying the code. If you only download it to see what it does, it just allows you to open your cache, dump the obj.dat file, and display the compass image. This is being released for learning purposes. Unless, of course, you want to build onto it and make it repack (If you do this, share please >.>). Here's a small screenshot I took first... [img]http://img22.imageshack.us/img22/1996/cacheextract.png[/img]
[b][url=http://www.mediafire.com/?nzmmf0l2nyw]Download Source with EXE[/url][/b]
Extracting stuff is pretty simple. In fact, it's done the same way as the client does it. You should just be able to look at the code and figure it out from there. If not, then this isn't something you want to look at.
Oh, and finally, a bunch of people are going to find this useless. But like I said, it's for learning purposes so you don't have to look at the client or other tools which do other things, or a base to build off of.
[b]Other Credits[/b] -Galkon - I used your refactored client, and that's where I got all the code from. -Miss. Silabsoft - If it weren't for you, I probably would have just done the "cache editor add-on".

item.title: Cache Extractor (C#)
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“r r r, post:22, topic:328558”]Could you reupload I would have liked to take a look at this.[/quote]It’s not worth it. I compiled it all to a DLL file to use in any C# project now, which will be included with my newest project that will be released, and the source code is just converted Java code.

Read full topic

item.title: Cache Extractor (C#)
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:16, topic:328558”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=424945.msg3122252#msg3122252 date=1265644709]
Hmm, i have an extractor, but its only useful for the getting models, maps, and other good stuff that the idx’s are used for. Good job Lin
[/quote]It’s funny because that’s what I’ve been trying to get. I don’t know how to get them, so I’ve looked at the client and I assumed I needed the on-demand fetcher working, which I can’t get. Would you mind explaining to me how you got them?[/quote]

I actually forget how i got it, but i would be willing to share it with ya.

Read full topic

item.title: Cache Extractor (C#)
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

idx0 = gamedata - icons,textures,items,locations…
idx1 = models
idx2 = anim files
idx3 = music
idx4 = maps

item.title: Cache Extractor (C#)
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:13, topic:328558”][quote author=Lin link=topic=424945.msg3121700#msg3121700 date=1265577391]
K just to let everyone know, I’ve worked on this more and made it load the on-demand stuff and will be updating it later today. As for something else, it turns out the Decompressor class has a method allowing you to write to the cache (method235), which is what you all use to add custom models. So that’s one thing less to work on.
[/quote]
except it does not change the crc tables

“model_version”, “anim_version”, “midi_version”, “map_version”
“model_crc”, “anim_crc”, “midi_crc”, “map_crc”

model_index
map_index
anim_index
midi_index[/quote]Ya but it’s not like anyone puts them to good use

Alright. After a long time of working with it, there’s a small chance I have gotten somewhere. I have to perform several more tests though before I can be sure.

Read full topic

item.title: Cache Extractor (C#)
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“licorish55, post:7, topic:328558”][quote author=AuraDevil link=topic=424945.msg3121434#msg3121434 date=1265562679]
Jagex’ client code was written with speed in mind, and not cleanliness.
[/quote]

How would you know?[/quote]
You can tell by just looking at it that it is obviously not designed with maintainability in mind.

Plus, Its common sense, If the code is going to be executed every time the client boots then you cant have it taking 5 minutes to load just the cache. Speed is the highest priority.

Read full topic

item.title: Cache Extractor (C#)
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

AuraDevil:

Jagex’ client code was written with speed in mind, and not cleanliness.

How would you know?

Read full topic

item.title: Cache Extractor (C#)
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

I’d highly advise against just ripping and modifying Jagex’ code. Jagex’ client code was written with speed in mind, and not cleanliness. You’re much better off writing your own constructs and so on that are easier to maintain and adapt to what you need to do. I fell into that trap with the first edition of the cache suite and lost the motivation to rewrite it all once I’d realised what I’d done.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Download Source with EXE
